Hello everyone,
I'm working over a real Hilbert space E and want to use the Riesz representation lemma. inner_product_space.to_dual from mathlib gives me an equivalence E ‚âÉ‚Çõ‚Çó·µ¢[‚Üëconj] normed_space.dual ùïú E, from which one can get an antilinear map normed_space.dual ‚Ñù E ‚Üí‚Çõ‚Çó[‚Üëconj] E. How can I get a linear map from this? I'm not sure how to begin...
@Daniel Roca Gonz√°lez It is designed to "just work". An antilinear map over ‚Ñù is definitionally a linear map.

import analysis.inner_product_space.dual

noncomputable theory

variables {E : Type*} [inner_product_space ‚Ñù E] [complete_space E]

example : E ‚âÉ‚Çó·µ¢[‚Ñù] normed_space.dual ‚Ñù E := inner_product_space.to_dual ‚Ñù E
wow I can't believe I didn't try this, thank you. Yeah this works just fine.
Thanks a lot. I think I had understood that linear maps are defined as semilinear maps, but I somehow didn't make the connection that ‚Üëconj is equal to the identity definitionally
